div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The Havana Post, June 26, 1900
div1.p: QUEMADOS SITUATION.

Dr. Stark Has the Fever Well Under
Control.

Non-Immunes Have Been Forced to Leave
Quemados and Are Living in Tents--No
Danger of Disease Spreading to Camp
Columbia--Eleven Cases.

There is not the slightest occasion for
alarm in the yellow fever situation at
Quemados, and there is every reason for
the belief of the authorities, and espe-
cially the surgeons, that not another
case of the disease will originate there.

A member of THE POST'S staff visited
Quemados Sunday for the express pur-
pose of learning all the facts in connec-
tion with the prevalence of yellow fever
there. He first visited the town and ob-
served the precautions being taken there
to prevent the spread of the disease. The
little city was almost as quiet as a grave-
yard. All the saloons which were opened
when the soldiers first arrived were
closed. These saloons are on General
Lee street, where they could command
the trade of the soldiers as they made
their way to and from the camp. They
were of a low order, of that class known
in the states as dives. One of the wooden
shacks adjoining one of these saloons
where a case of fever developed was de-
stroyed by fire, while all of the houses in
the infected zone, which faces General Lee
street and runs for one block back, have
been disinfected.

Captain Stark, Surgeon United States
Army, who was next in command to
Major Kean, and who succeeded that of-
ficial as chief surgeon of the department
of Havana and Pinar del Rio on the staff
of General Lee, is a young man, but the
steps he has adopted in the interest of
the public health has demonstrated that
he is in every way capable and efficient.
He has adopted a course which cannot
fail to stamp out the disease, and in pur-
suing his course has acted positively, re-
fusing to be influenced by the protests or
appeals of those who have been com-
pelled to obey his instructions.

When he assumed charge of the chief
surgeon's office quarantine measures
were already in force, but these he ex-
tended and made more severe. Soldiers
are not permitted to enter the city unless
they are provided with passes, and every
soldier who is absent from his command
without leave for six hours is arrested
and sent to the detention [unclear] up, where
[unclear]
five days and where he is given work on
the new road by way of exercise. All of
the civilian employes of the government
have been moved from the city and are
in a camp of detention near the post hos-
pital. They are constantly under sur-
veillance and their temperatures are
taken three times each day. All civilian
non-immunes who were living in the city
have been moved to a camp about one
half mile this side of the city, where they
are pleasantly situated on a hill and
where they have been provided with
tents well-floored. They are fed by the
quartermaster's department, being al-
lowed everything they desire, even in-
cluding candy for the children. Dr. Stark
visits them every day and exercises great
care in looking after their welfare. There
are thirty people at this camp.

Those who are detained at the camp
will be kept there for a period of five
days dating from Sunday morning, and
will then be permitted to go where they
please. In the event that none of them
have homes they will be permitted to re-
main at the camp and will continue to
draw the same rations which they at
present receive. They will not be per-
mitted to return to Quemados, as no civ-
ilian non-immune will be permitted to
live in the city until after November 1st.
Those connected with the surgeon's de-
partment claim that this will have the
effect of completely stamping out the
disease, since there will be no material
upon which to feed.

As to the prevalence of fever among
the troops at Camp Columbia there is
absolutely no danger. Abundant pre-
cautions have been taken and the condi-
tion of the camp is clean. As to sanita-
tion, Camp Columbia is an ideal camp.
There is a complete system of sewerage
and the greatest care has been taken to
keep the camp clean. The reporter spent
over an hour at the camp and made a
thorough investigation of the barracks,
kitchens, sinks, etc. There is not a place
around the camp which is not in a perfect
sanitary condition. Yellow fever could
not live in such a place.

A few soldiers have been taken sick
with the disease, but in every instance
their exposure has been traced to the in-
fected zone at Quemados. The troops
are in no danger whatever.

The record of yellow fever since it first
originated shows the infected zone to
have been confined to the district within
the ropes. There have been twenty-six
cases since the 24th of May. There are
now eleven cases under treatment at the
hospitals, as follows:

Major Kean, chief surgeon of the de-
partment of Havana and Pinar del Rio,
who acquired the disease while living in
the infected zone.

Captain Hepburn, who lived in the in-
fected zone.

John D. Sutton, civilian, clerk of Major
Kean, who lived in the infected zone.

Mac Olsen, civilian, carpenter, who
spent several days with a friend in the
infected zone.

Frank Keating, civilian employe of the
corral, who acquired the fever from ex-
posure at Quemados.

Thomas Carter, private in the signal
corps, who lived in the same house as
Captain Hepburn in the infected zone.

John Marfardt, German civilian car-
penter, who was employed by an engi-
neering company, and who was taken
sick almost as soon as he arrived at
Quemados. It is believed that he con-
tracted the disease on San Ignacio
street, where he lived.

A tailor by the name of Hamburg, who
had a tailor shop in the infected zone.

Chas. J. Marhefka, a private of Troop
B. Seventh Cavalry, who was a friend
of Hamburg, and who spent much time
in his shop.

A French woman, whose name was
not obtained, who lived in the infected
zone and who is in the hospital some dis-
tance from the camp of detention.

A teamster, who contracted the dis-
ease in Quemados.

The deaths which have occurred since
the disease broke out are as follows:

Major Frank H. Edmunds, acting in-
spector general on the staff of General
Lee.

John Lutz, an Austrian who ran a
restaurant on General Lee street.

Two Suzer brothers, Austrian tailors,
who had a shop on General Lee street.

Mrs. Finn, an American lady aged
eighty years, who lived in Quemados.

The hospital facilities are good. At
the post yellow fever hospital there are
two immune doctors, six female immune
nurses and six non-immune corps boys,
who volunteered their services to wait
upon the sick.

The surgeons have endeavored to have
General Lee leave the palace for the sum-
mer for fear he will contract the disease,
but the General has positively refused to
do so.

The reporter visited Quemados in re-
sponse to an invitation from General
Lee and was accorded every facility by
the General and his staff for pursuing
his inquiry.

A good many Cuban passengers sailed
on the Plant steamer which left here yes-
terday for Port Tampa. Most of them
are going to Tampa to spend the sum-
mer with relatives.
